http://blogs.msdn.com/b/ie/archive/2012/07/12/ie10-user-agent-string-update.aspx cross-platform :/
looks like they are bold enough to break the Desktop/Phone/Tablet taxonomy and instead go with a touch / no touch
unless, of course, they later ship IE10 for phones with yet another UA string anyway
in which case they could have said Tablet instead of touch for compat with Firefox and Opera
it doesn't really seem compatible with Microsoft's platform vision of being able to interact with everything in whatever way you want either
if the UA advertises touch and I have a keyboard hooked up there's a fair chance I'm going to be in trouble, which seems kind of contrary to recent Microsoft vision announcements
fwiw, I expect the strategy of putting touch screens on desktops to flop for ergonomic and aesthetic reasons
annevk, maybe you should get yourself hired by MS :)
hsivonen: well yeah, me too
hsivonen: just pointing out some inconsistency here :)
annevk: well, Mozilla's platform engineers supposedly prefer capability sniffing, but we still cater to non-top-tier Web authors who want to assume a Desktop/Tablet/Phone taxonomy and UA sniff for it
seems bad for fingerprinting, but I guess it's exposed in other ways already
(though it does make it easier)
I should note that Opera's local-Presto products do it, too
In which light I find it odd that Opera Mini doesn't expose tabletness in the UA string
even though Mini spews out fingerprinting surface without any concern by exposing the exact device model
I have attempted to fix various bits of our UA string, but somehow missed out when we started screwing it up again :/
I was trying to advocate that Mozilla do it exactly like Opera (with "Mobi" and "Tablet"), but we ended up doing it with "Mobile" and "Tablet"
which still allows clueful people handle Firefox and Opera form-factor sniffing using the same code
not sure how much of a lost cause it is to design UA strings to be nicely sniffable by clueful sniffers

wonders how long until )]} prepended to JSON becomes an official part of JSON
hsivonen: prepended how?
SimonSapin: Characters ")]}" at the start of the file before normal JSON content
SimonSapin: in order to make sure the file is *not* a valid JS program
hsivonen, isn't the whole point of JSON supposed to be that it is syntactically valid JavaScript?
which sites prepend such characters to their JSON?
Lachy: well, JSON works independent of eval nowadays (and also in non-JS languages)
yeah, I know. But JSON.parse() doesn't support prepending )]}, does it?
Lachy: the point of )]} is to prevent cross-side data theft by overriding JS Array and then loading the file as a script
hsivonen: is this for security reasons as described in http://flask.pocoo.org/docs/security/#json-security ?
Lachy: it doesn't support it to my knowledge, but I haven't tested
Lachy: presumably Google uses this for source maps
Lachy: the source maps spec explicitly extends JSON like this
SimonSapin: yes
the source maps spec could use some Hixie-style spec writing. I will have to send some feedback.

yeah, that
so I'm now looking into rewriting the about: URI spec properly (since the IETF has now taken it in the wrong direction).

I need to figure out a term to use, instead of "reserved about URI", which means any URI defined by a specification for use in a defined context, but where it doesn't suggest any kind of exclusivity of that URI for that spec.

I'm also defining it such that all about: URIs other than about:blank are non-dereferencable, outside of application-specific uses, which avoids any possible conflict of two specs using the same about: URI, and thus removing any need for a normative registry..
TIL about the “octal escapes in regular expression literals” compatibility requirement for JavaScript: http://mathias.html5.org/specs/javascript/#octal-escapes-in-regular-expression-literals
Lachy: how on earth did the ietf manage to screw up something as simple as about: ???
zcorpan: i'm literally working on a fix to the bug issue today (spent most of yesterday on it too)
zcorpan: (writing a script that will clone the bugs)

well, they define things that just don't match reality. percent-encoding is not supported, for example, and yet is defined in the spec. I would have changed it, but the feedback was handled around the time someone else took over editing.

they also introduced a silly registry that gives exclusivity of a given about: URI to the first spec that defines it, rather than realising that independent uses of the same token in different specs doesn't conflict in any case.
they also now fail to define how about:blank is handled.
In their defense, nobody knows how about:blank needs to be handled
so I think about: URIs, at least for use in specifications, are to be handled as opaque identifiers, rather than real URLs.
Ms2ger, it needs to be handled as an opaque identifier not subject to URL normalisation, and behaves as though it returns an empty UTF-8 encoded HTML document.
<iframe src="about:blan%6B"> is not the same as <iframe src="about:blank"> in any implementation.
But clearly it *should* be!
that depends on the reasons for browsers not applying any normalisation. Boris sent feedback before to the IETF list about this, and the potential for security implications for changing it.
Ms2ger, also, despite the about: spec being available and saying that for a long time now, not one browser has changed. So I'd rather have a spec that documents reality.
when in doubt, let bz take precedence over the IETF
s/the IETF/everyone else/, pretty much
Lachy: good times
Lachy: TabAtkins_ apparently managed to register about:invalid with the iana folks
Yup, it was pretty easy.
hober, yes, I know. I saw that.

hober: TabAtkins_: fwiw, CSS should use about:blank, just like every other place where we lack a base URL
Lachy: Ms2ger: %-normalization does not appear to happen in the browser, so supporting just "about:blank" should be pretty trivial
Lachy: Ms2ger: especially once the URL specification is somewhat more in shape, though not sure how much of that I'll do during vacation, other than a bit of planning

not validator valid

scott_gonzalez: you'd need to remove the attribute

annevk, right, which is why I think percent normalisation should be abandoned. It might be easier to just say that when used by a specification in a specific context, they are non-dereferencable magic tokens that look like URLs, but which aren't really. Except for about:blank, no other about: URI actually needs to refer to any specific resource.
TabAtkins_: what you mean with de-magicify iframes
The point of the default value for attr(foo url) is that it shouldn't every be dereferenceable, no matter what context it appears in.
annevk: Like, "content: frame(http://foo);"

annevk: The problem that I alluded to with my "symmetry" comment is that we have mechanisms in CSS now that have special behavior for "invalid" URLs, that don't dereference to a resource of the expected type (the image() function).
but it's going to be confusing when people add comments all over
annevk: i'm very open to suggestions for making it better
annevk: It's reasonable to assume that, in the future, if we have properties that expect to take a URL pointing to an HTML page, that we might have similar functionality.
annevk: So, for symmetry, might as well claim a URL up-front that will work for all media types.
Tabatkins: why would it ever point to about:blank directly?
Tabatkins: could you give an example?
Because of attr(foo url), when the element doesn't have a "foo" attribute.
Tabatkins: ooh, why wouldn't you fallback to nothing?
What is "nothing"?
Tabatkins: is this mainly about the computed value?
Yeah.
Tabatkins: wouldn't the computed value be "foo"?
hm, bug in my script; it didn't properly update the previous bug
why not
annevk: No, that would be weird.  It would mean that attr(foo url) computes to either a string or a url, depending on whether the attribute exists.
We can't do useful type-checking with that.
And computing to url(foo) is no good either, because that's potentially a valid resource.

is there any sort of spec for txt-to-html conversion or vice versa?
jtcranmer: there are many text-based lightweight markup languages that can convert to HTML: markdown, restructuredText, …
that doesn't answer my question :-)
then, what do you mean by txt-to-html?
jtcranmer: there's no standardized way other than lots of de facto standards
there are de facto standards at least for things like *bold* /italics/ _underline_ |code|
yes, and markdown formalizes them somewhat
and I've noticed that things like copying HTML and pasting as plain text tend to do things like turn <ol> into # and <ul> into * or similar ventures
there are many variants, like `code` instead of |code|
if you pick on precisely, you get something like markdown
http://daringfireball.net/projects/markdown/syntax
Yes, Markdown is generally accepted as the "standard" txt-markup language now.  There are several incompatible extensions, but the core is stable.
how about the other direction?
it has been done, but it is always lossy
I don't doubt that it is
It's actually a good bit easier.  Just look up what markdown can encode, then reverse it in the obvious way.

foo

becomes "foo\n===", etc.
Tabatkins: easier because we already have HTML parsers?
Yes, it's a simple tree-walk then.
I'm assuming this is done in the browser.
Outside of it, the HTML parser is harder than the Markdown parser. ^_^
okay. I guess md-to-html is alsa just a tree-walk once the Markdown is parsed
also*

jtcranmer: an e-mail client receiving text/plain e-mail doesn't have to convert to HTML, it has to convert to pixels.

there's no line wrapping in text/plain either :-)
Hixie - what the rendering engine does with text/plain is outside of scope.  <pre> mandates no wrapping during render.  text/plain does no such thing.

identifier->data mapping outlives the time blob URL can be successfully parsed

once the revocation happens the identifier's revoke flag is set which causes further parsing of blob URLs using that identifier to fail (turn into about:invalid)

i guess i think of a list/map of stuff that you insert into as needing to remove it explicitly, where attaching data to an object just feels GC-y

well anyway
with the URL-property approach, do you think leaving releasing to QoI is good enough?
one thing is that specs still need to pay attention to it, to make sure it results in the right conclusion
eg. that they don't accidentally require keeping blob references around longer than expected
I guess reloading should fail afterwards? e.g. <iframe>.contentWindow.location.reload()
(such as if xhr allowed calling send() multiple times per open(), that would have happened)
hmm
any time you're able to reload the data later it'd force keeping the blob around ... so it's a judgement call
can't fetch just free it up?
after fetch completes, clear it from the URL object?
so if the URL object is reused by the API after that, it fails
and if the API reuses it before the fetch completes, it works

i guess it could, with two caveats: 1: it'd prevent ever using it multiple times (maybe there's never any reason to) and 2: it'd still depend on QoI for freeing (because you might eg. never call xhr.send() at all)
well yeah, unused objects that might be used will use memory
not sure if there's a way around that
i mean, after discarding the xhr object
(if you call open() and then keep the xhr around forever and never send() it, yeah, keeping the blob around forever is what the user is asking for)
yeah the implementation would need to make sure that the objects stored on the XHR object are freed
including the URL object
and everything it has
that seems pretty straightforward though
XHR.collect() -> will collect the associated URL object which will collect itself
yeah
not sure when there would be a multiple times scenario
though you'd also want to release the blob ref when entering DONE, without waiting for GC (but that's also just QoI)
if you enter done fetch has finished and you'd be required to

uh
annevk - I've heard similar comparisons of microdata and RDFa, of course even more so I hear that they're both still too much of a bother (e.g. compared to microformats).

I was originally more optimistic about microdata, but it turns out it (and RDFa) suffer from the "bolt-on" problem (ala longdesc) - they're just not part of web designers' normal workflow, so they get ignored.
in contrast, all web designers spend time in class attributes, so to put in a few microformats classes while they're in there is anywhere from trivial to easy.
I find all of them too much of a bother typically :)
aha, tantek!
haven't seen much useful stuff done with them
agrees with anne :-)
as a web developer i have no idea what either of them are, and the drama around both of them makes me not very interested in finding out :)
indeed, if it doesn't seem useful to you, then don't bother is a reasonable short-term prioritization approach
annevk - "too much of a bother" - often true unfortunately, no matter what markup we're talking about (from <section> to <abbr> to RDFa)
yeah, I stopped using <abbr> too
that's something dictionaries can solve

it's pretty clear from years of teach web designers, that one must demonstrate that some semantic markup provides benefits to them that outweighs the "bother" in order for them to do it and keep doing it.
<section> I might use if I had more complex sites
this can be improved by increasing the benefits received, or lowering the amount of bother, or both.
currently using <h2> works for me
i wish i had <section> available when i started the html spec
that would have made moving stuff around way easier
as it is now i have a horrible tangle of pragmas to bump the hx numbers up and down on output
with microformats 2, we're focusing first on lowering the "bother" (since that worked for microformats in the first place, as compared to things like XML data islands etc.).
ah yeah, for that it's super useful
